context: The second series of experiments was performed to investigate the performance of the better catalyst, MnO/Fe2O3, on the catalytic conversion of both the VOCs. The operating parameters and ranges for both the VOCs were inlet temperature (150–400°C), VOC concentration (50–150ppm), space velocity (30,000–80,000h−1), and O2 concentration (0.1–20.8%). The third series of experiments was a life-test of the catalyst to identify the sulfur-poisoning effects of both the VOCs. Reagent grade liquid dimethyl sulfide and dimethyl disulfide were injected into the VOC generator, which was kept at a constant temperature of −5°C for (CH3)2S and 30°C for (CH3)2S2. Purged N2 carried the vaporized VOCs which were mixed with dilute air and N2 to simulate the waste gas from a typical petrochemical plant. The simulated gas was injected into the catalytic reactor in an electrically heated furnace. Gas samples (1ml) were taken before and after the reaction, by an on-line autosampler.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, methylsulfanylmethane and dimethyl sulfide are both volatile organic compounds (VOCs) being investigated for their catalytic conversion performance using a specific catalyst, MnO/Fe2O3. The experiments focus on the effects of these compounds on catalyst performance, particularly regarding sulfur-poisoning effects. While both compounds are related as VOCs in the study, the specific interactions or differences between them are not elaborated upon in detail.
llm_generation.reason: The score of 3 reflects a moderate relevance, as both methylsulfanylmethane and dimethyl sulfide are part of the same experimental setup concerning catalytic conversion. However, their specific relationship or interaction is not deeply explored beyond their inclusion in the study.
